<DoxygenPage pluginConfig={pluginConfig}>

## Description {#details}

<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/twine">Twine</a> - A lightweight data structure for efficiently representing the concatenation of temporary values as strings.

A <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/twine">Twine</a> is a kind of rope, it represents a concatenated string using a binary-tree, where the string is the preorder of the nodes. Since the <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/twine">Twine</a> can be efficiently rendered into a buffer when its result is used, it avoids the cost of generating temporary values for intermediate string results – particularly in cases when the <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/twine">Twine</a> result is never required. By explicitly tracking the type of leaf nodes, we can also avoid the creation of temporary strings for conversions operations (such as appending an integer to a string).

A <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/twine">Twine</a> is not intended for use directly and should not be stored, its implementation relies on the ability to store pointers to temporary stack objects which may be deallocated at the end of a statement. Twines should only be used as const references in arguments, when an API wishes to accept possibly-concatenated strings.

Twines support a special &#39;null&#39; value, which always concatenates to form itself, and renders as an empty string. This can be returned from APIs to effectively nullify any concatenations performed on the result.

<b>Implementation</b> 

Given the nature of a <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/twine">Twine</a>, it is not possible for the <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/twine">Twine</a>&#39;s concatenation method to construct interior nodes; the result must be represented inside the returned value. For this reason a <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/twine">Twine</a> object actually holds two values, the left- and right-hand sides of a concatenation. We also have nullary <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/twine">Twine</a> objects, which are effectively sentinel values that represent empty strings.

Thus, a <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/twine">Twine</a> can effectively have zero, one, or two children. The 
<SectionUser title="See Also">
isNullary(),
</SectionUser>


<SectionUser title="See Also">
isUnary(), and
</SectionUser>


<SectionUser title="See Also">
isBinary() predicates exist <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64expandpseudoinsts-cpp/#a4cfc8b177e8521a4b496ae2edff6244f">for</a> testing the number of <a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/#acc2e6a2001a5f102f18060a53520e82b">children</a>.
</SectionUser>

We maintain a number of invariants on <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/twine">Twine</a> objects (FIXME: Why):
<ul>
<li>Nullary twines are always represented with their Kind on the left-hand side, and the Empty kind on the right-hand side.</li>
<li>Unary twines are always represented with the value on the left-hand side, and the Empty kind on the right-hand side.</li>
<li>If a <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/twine">Twine</a> has another <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/twine">Twine</a> as a child, that child should always be binary (otherwise it could have been folded into the parent).</li>
</ul>


These invariants are check by 
<SectionUser title="See Also">
isValid().
</SectionUser>

<b>Efficiency</b> Considerations

The <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/twine">Twine</a> is designed to yield efficient and small code for common situations. For this reason, the <a href="#a529bd775f25e1c6ea4a96b34a5d8bde6">concat()</a> method is inlined so that concatenations of leaf nodes can be optimized into stores directly into a single stack allocated object.

In practice, not all compilers can be trusted to optimize <a href="#a529bd775f25e1c6ea4a96b34a5d8bde6">concat()</a> fully, so we provide two additional methods (and accompanying operator+ overloads) to guarantee that particularly important cases (cstring plus <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/stringref">StringRef</a>) codegen as desired.

Definition at line 81 of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/adt/twine-h">Twine.h</a>.

### toNullTerminatedStringRef {#a5d968bc337af0be1f18813553a046df6}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>StringRef Twine::toNullTerminatedStringRef (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/smallvectorimpl">SmallVectorImpl</a>&lt; char &gt; &amp; Out) const</>}>
This returns the twine as a single null terminated <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/stringref">StringRef</a> if it can be represented as such.

Otherwise the twine is written into the given <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/smallvector">SmallVector</a> and a <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/stringref">StringRef</a> to the <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/smallvector">SmallVector</a>&#39;s data is returned.

The returned <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/stringref">StringRef</a>&#39;s size does not include the null terminator.

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/adt/twine-h/#l00504">504</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/include/include/llvm/include/llvm/adt/twine-h">Twine.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/support/twine-cpp/#l00037">37</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/support/twine-cpp">Twine.cpp</a>.
</MemberDefinition>
